results.title: How to make a truck
results.brief_description: Looks at the relatively small scale manufacture of trucks for specialized applications in the United States. Provides a simple but comprehensive explanation of the assembly line and the entire process of truck production.

results.title: How to make a movie without a camera
results.creator_credit: Rainy Day Productions, Michael Warshaw and Mimi Warshaw
results.brief_description: Presents the results of efforts made to produce a film without a camera, using the following techniques to produce striking effects: vegetable dye colouring, felt-tipped pen, sprays and fingerprints all individually applied to clear leader; and scratching and perforating of opaque leader. The film is especially useful to young filmmakers.

results.title: How to make a movie
results.brief_description: Although short and largely created to practise the Straford Brothers’ unique approach to editing and transitions, this already shows their ambitions for scene and story. Here, a frustrated filmmaker tries to make a ‘classic.’

results.title: How to kill your husband
results.brief_description: Shirley’s father, a skilled mechanic and excellent drummer, suffered from heart disease. Shirley retells her father’s history, from the struggles of growing up during the depression to his now proud children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: How to keep from catching VD
results.brief_description: A health officer addresses a class of secondary school students about gonorrhea and syphilis. Using charts, he explains the immediate and long-range effects of each disease. Stress is placed on the possible prevention of the diseases through selective sexual behaviour, cleanliness and the use of mechanical devices.

results.title: How to keep a job
results.brief_description: Discusses the habits and attitudes that make for job success once the job is obtained. A man seeking a new job after being fired at his last job is interviewed by the Personnel director of a company and is told that employers want men who are dependable, willing to work, co-operate, loyal and possess initiative.

results.title: How to judge facts
results.brief_description: Designed to help students develop a technique for fact-finding, this film tells the story of a high school student who writes a sensational story for his school newspaper; his fellow students begin to learn to discount platitudes, false analogies, unfounded assumptions, and double meanings.

results.title: How to judge authorities
results.brief_description: A boy discovers a conflict between statements of “authorities” on a certain subject, and begins to make inquiries in order to evaluate the two statements. He considers the internal evidence on each “authority”, the experience from which each speaks, and the evidence of his own experience, in order to decide which, if either, “authority” is to be believed.

results.title: How to investigate vocations
results.brief_description: Intended to motivate youngsters to investigate vocations and determine the kinds of work for which they are best suited. The film illustrates how to interpret vocational guidance tests, how to apply their information to different vocations, how to raise questions related to a specific job and how to gain actual job experience by taking employment during vacations.
